data.text: Choose
CE marked PPE, and equipment that suits the user – consider the size, fit and weight of the PPE. If the users help choose it, they will be more likely to use it
If more than one item of PPE is worn at the same time, make sure they can be used together,
Instruct and train people how to use the PPE, eg train people to remove gloves without contaminating their skin. Tell them why it is needed, when to use it are the equipment limitations.

Never allow exemptions from wearing PPE for those jobs that ‘only take a few minutes'. Check with supplier on what PPE is appropriate – explain the job to them . If in doubt, seek further advice from a Trust Health and Safety Manager or Advisor.
MAINTENANCE – PPE must be properly looked after and stored when not in use, eg in a dry, clean cupboard. If it is reusable it must be cleaned and kept in good condition.
Think about:
Utilisation of correct replacement parts which match the original, eg respirator filters. Keeping replacement PPE available
Who is responsible for maintenance and how it is to be done
Employees must report l its loss, destruction or any fault in PPE to line manager.
MONITOR & REVIEW
Check regularly that PPE is used. If it isn't, find out why not
Safety signs can be a useful reminder that PPE should be worn
Take note of any changes in equipment, materials and methods – you may need to update what you provide
Introduction

The Health and Safety at Work etc Act 1974, and the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations 1992 places a legal duty on Mid & South Essex Hospitals Group (herein after referred to as the Trust) in relation to the provision and safe use of personal protective equipment (PPE) at work.

This Legislation exists to enforce good standards of safety and the aim of the Trust is to adhere to those standards by ensuring that PPE is supplied and used at work wherever there are risks to health and safety that cannot be adequately controlled in other ways. The Trust will further endeavour to ensure all its employees, voluntary workers, contractors and visitors recognise their responsibilities by actively ensuring that this policy and any accompanying procedures are adhered to
What do the Regulations Require?

The main requirement of the PPE at Work Regulations 1992 (as amended) is that personal protective equipment is to be supplied and used at work whenever there are risks to health and safety that cannot be adequately controlled in other ways. PPE is to be used as a last resort.
1.3.1  The Regulations also require that PPE:
Is properly assessed before use to ensure that it is suitable;
Is maintained and stored properly;
Is provided with instructions on how to use it safely;
Is correctly used by employees
Monitor usage of PPE
Take note of any changes in equipment, materials and methods
Purpose

This policy and procedure provides a framework to enable managers to undertake an adequate assessment to ensure suitable PPE is provided. It covers the general requirement to provide and maintain personal protective equipment (PPE) and ensure all staff receive appropriate information, instruction and training in PPE usage.

All those affected by this policy are expected to utilise PPE where it is deemed necessary and to report its loss or defect immediately to their line manager or supervisor. No charge shall be made by the Trust in respect of any item of PPE provided by the Trust in order to enable staff to perform a task safely.
Scope
Those who manage or undertake work where the assessment to risk has deemed usage of PPE is appropriate.
NHS Constitution
The Trust is committed to:
Designing and implementing services, policies and measures that meet the diverse needs of its population and workforce, ensuring that no individual or group is disadvantaged.
This Policy supports the NHS Constitution as follows:

The Trust aspires to the highest standards of excellence and professionalism in the provision of high-quality care that is safe, effective and focused on patient experience; in the planning and delivery of the clinical and other services it provides; in the people it employs and the education, training and development they receive; in the leadership and management of its organisations; and through its commitment to innovation and to the promotion and conduct of research to improve the current and future health and care of the population.
Definitions

table_items.text: All equipment (including clothing affording protection against the weather) which is intended to be worn or held by a person at work which protects them against one or more risks to their health and safety e.g. safety helmets, eye protection, high-visibility clothing, safety footwear and safety harnesses. For the purpose of this Policy PPE includes some of the following items when worn specifically for health and safety needs: Protective clothing Aprons and gloves Safety footwear Safety helmets High visibility waistcoats / Jckets Clothing designed specifically to protect the wearer Gowns and sleeve protectors Ear defenders Protective equipment: Eye protectors / safety glasses (not glasses issued for DSE use) Face / surgical masks Respirators (Aerosol Generating Procedures) Safety harnesses Other:

UV Protection (sun cream) Equipment used for managing violence e.g. shields. NB. Personal safety devices, such as Blick and lone worker devices are classed as ‘Work Equipment'. Therefore, where issued must be used in all circumstances. This Policy does not apply to: Ordinary working clothes / uniforms which do not specifically protect the health and safety of the wearer PPE which is covered by other specific Regulations e.g. Noise, Radiation and Asbestos

PPE is defined in the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations as: “all equipment which is intended to be worn or held by a person who is at work and which protects him / her against one or more risks to his / her health and safety”.

Respiratory Protective Equipment (RPE) is a particular type of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) used to protect the individual wearer against inhalation of hazardous substances in the workplace air

The Conformité Européene (CE) marking signifies that the PPE satisfies certain basic safety requirements and in some cases will have been tested and certified by an independent body (European Conformity)
UK product and service quality trade mark which is owned and operated by The British Standards Institution (BSI Group).
The person who utilises PPE (For the purpose of this policy the words “wearer” and “user” shall have the same meaning)
A sign prescribing specific behaviour (eg ‘eye protection must be worn');

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

Health  &  Safety  Committee  (HSC)  Health  and  safety  Management  Group (MSMG)  are  to  ensure  that  this  policy  and  procedure  is  regularly  reviewed, updated where necessary and approve this document.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust

6.2.1 The Chief Exectutive shall be responsible for ensuring that this Policy is implemented in order to enable the Trust to comply with the Health & Safety at Work etc Act 1974 and the Personal Protective Equipment at Work Regulations 1992.

6.2.2 Directorates / Managers / Heads of Service shall ensure that PPE requirements are considered as a last resort (excepting for certain clinical circumstances) when risks are identified and assessed through suitable and sufficient risk assessments. The findings must be recorded.
6.2.3 Managers must ensure that where is it deemed there is a need for PPE to be worn it is correct for the particular risks involved and for the circumstance of its use.
6.2.4 Managers/Supervisors/ Authorised persons/Competent persons will ensure the following:
An assessment of PPE is carried out to ensure the correct selection of PPE;
That where necessary special arrangements are made for individuals with health conditions that could affect the use of PPE;
All PPE carries a CE or BS mark;
PPE is maintained where required (includes cleaning, disinfection, examination prior to use, replacement, repair and testing);
Appropriate records of tests and examination where required are carried out and kept ;
Clean and dry and appropriate storage facilities for PPE are provided;

That suitable information, instruction and appropriate training is provided to staff before wearing of the PPE (wearers must be trained in its proper use, how to fit correctly and wear it and what its limitations are) and that training records are in place and kept up to date;
In circumstances where mandatory signage is required that this is displayed and maintained (see appendix 9);
That staff use PPE in accordance with the Trusts instructions and / or the manufacturer's instructions for its use;

There is a sufficient stock of PPE and this is made available to staff All PPE designed for single use must be used once and that staff know how to dispose of it appropriately in line with the Trusts Management of Waste Policy;
There is a local procedure in place for reporting loss or defective PPE and that any local procedure sits in line with this policy;
That staff use the PPE for all activities carried out whether undertaken on Trust premises or not (i.e. patient's homes);
Ill health, incidents or near misses relating to the use of PPE are reported in line with the Trusts incident reporting procedure 15.01 and are investigated and remedial action taken;
Where appropriate ensure that contractors utilise PPE in accordance with the Trust Control of Contractors Policy.

6.2.5 Infection Prevention and Control staff will provide appropriate advice and guidance to managers in determining the correct type of PPE where there is for example a risk of blood and / or body fluid spillage.
6.2.6 Managers will ensure risk assessments are reviewed / updated where there are any changes in equipment, materials and methods and that all staff are informed of the change
6.2.7 Health, Safety and Manual Handling team will ensure the following:
This document is reviewed, and updated with any changes that may come about with changes in legislation that affects this policy/procedure;
Provision of health and safety guidance and assistance on the policy/procedure and producing risk assessments;
Provision of manual handling guidance (where applicatble) and assistance on the policy/procedure and producing risk assessments;
To advise on the selection of PPE;
To ensure that this policy and procedure is updated as required;
To monitor via Estates & Facilities stores person the administering, ordering and distribution records of PPE to Estates and Facilities Maintenance Staff.
6.2.8 All employees have a responsibility to ensure:
They use all PPE provided for them correctly at all times. This applies to all activities carried out whether undertaken on Trust premises or not (i.e. patients homes).
They attend any training in relation to the safe use of PPE and comply with the training and any instructions and information provided to them such as manufacturers' instructions.
Check the condition of their PPE before using it.
They store, clean and maintain their PPE correctly and where appropriate clean and disinfect PPE.
They use PPE designed for single use once and then dispose of it safely in line with the Trusts Management of Waste Policy.
Report any losses, defects or other problems with PPE to their manager immediately and under no circumstance use defective / damaged PPE.
Notify of any changes in equipment, materials and methods to their manager and co-workers / patients to allow for risk assessments to be reviewed / up dated.

Inform their manager of any health conditions or any other reasons that may affect the safe use of PPE so that they are not exposed to risk at any time. This will enable special arrangements to be made where necessary to provide for their health and safety.

Report any injuries, ill health, incidents or near misses relating to the use of PPE immediately to their manager and complete a Trust incident report in accordance with the Trusts incident reporting procedures.
Refer to Local EFM ‘Work at Height Procedure' for specific duties assigned to EFM internal and appointed contractual staff regarding maintenance and projects associated work at height tasks for:
Head of Estates;
Appointed Persons;
Competent Persons;
Estates and Facilities Maintenance Supervisor's and Team Leaders;
Project Managers/those overseeing contractors;
EFM On Call Tradesperson;
Contractors;
Health, Safety & Risk Department;
Maintenance Personnel;
EFM Quality Assurance Department.
Risk Assessment
Risk assessments are a requirement under the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 which involves identifying hazards and evaluating the risks involved.

Some types of PPE provide high levels of protection, however, none provide 100% protection  therefore,  PPE  should  be  considered  as  a  ‘last  resort'  when  other control measures have been considered and either implemented or proven to be ineffective. This is because the effectiveness of PPE can be easily compromised, e.g. by not being chosen, fitted or worn properly and this puts the wearer and others at risk. Therefore, the following hierarchy of controls must be considered before the control of PPE.
N.B.: For Infection, Prevention and Control (IPC) purposes there will be certain circumstances when gloves must be worn. Always discuss with the IPC Team when in doubt.
The hierarchy of controls are:
Eliminate the hazard at source, e.g. use a non-hazardous substance instead of a hazardous one;
Reduce the hazard at source, e.g. use a substance less hazardous than the one used at present ;
Remove the person from the hazard, e.g. replace the person with a machine or automotive process;
Contain the hazard by enclosure, e.g. isolate the hazard by using an enclosure;
Reduce employee exposure, e.g. reduce the exposure time for both substances and noise;
Personal Protective Equipment usage, (e.g. gloves, goggles for substances) should be considered following all of the above controls.

To allow the correct type of PPE to be chosen, managers should carefully consider the different hazards in the workplace. This will enable an assessment to be made of the type of PPE suitable to protect against the hazard, for the work to be carried out.
Consider the following when assessing whether PPE is suitable:
Is it appropriate for the risks involved and the conditions of the place where exposure to the risk may occur i.e. falling objects, liquid splashes from bodily fluids?
Does it prevent or adequately control the risks involved?
What are the needs of the job and demands it places on the wearer?
If more than one type of PPE is required, is it compatible?

PPE should be effective in terms of protecting the wearer against the hazard identified, including the period of time for which it is to be worn. Use of PPE should not increase the risks to the wearer arising from reduced visibility, dexterity, environmental comfort etc.
Process
To facilitate operational application of this policy managers should refer to the following appendices:
Appendix 1 Line Managers Responsibilities. To assist them in carrying out their line managers responsibilities.
Appendix 2 Checklist for Considering the Appropriateness and Suitability of Personal Protective Equipment to assist in carrying out risk assessments for PPE.
Appendix 3 Checklist for the Selection of Personal Protective Equipment
Appendix 4 Guidance for Dealing with Blood / Body Fluid Spillage
Appendix 5 Prepare and Protect Guidance for healthcare staff on personal protective equipment NHS England
Appendix 6 Steps to put on / take off Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) including Coverall
Appendix 7 Steps to put on / take off Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) including Gown
Appendix 8 Removal and Disposal of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)
Appendix 9 Register of Issue and Visual Inspection of Personal Protective
Equipment
8.1.1 PPE can be used as a short-term emergency measure while other control measures are assessed or for occasional work of short duration when there is no other alternative.
8.1.2 Trust Risk Assessment or local task specific assessment templates) documentation must be used in all instances where there is a significant risk to the person and /or others.
Maintenance and Storage of PPE Ensure PPE is:
Maintained and stored in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions;
Suitable storage facilities must be provided for PPE to be kept whilst not in use;
Storage should provide adequate protection against contamination, damage, damp, effects of exposure to harmful substances, theft or loss;
Kept clean and in good repair;
Follow the manufacturer's maintenance schedule;
Simple maintenance of non-disposable PPE can be carried out by the trained wearer, but more intricate repairs should only carried according to the manufacturer's guidelines by competent person(s);
Complies with replacement periods and shelf lives.
8.2.1 Staff should carry out a visual check of PPE before and after use to ensure that there are not defects.
8.2.2 PPE with defects should not be worn and staff should report any defects to their manager immediately and cease using it.
8.2.3 Disposable PPE i.e. gloves, aprons etc. should be disposed of after a single use in clinical waste bins/bags.
Maintenance and Storage of PPE

8.3.1 The Trust will take all reasonable steps to ensure that PPE is being used where it has been deemed appropriate. This provision includes ensuring equipment is being used and maintained correctly in accordance with the manufacturer's guidelines.
8.3.2 Managers should ensure regular audits are carried out to ensure compliance.
8.3.3 Any defective items should be removed from service pending repair/replacement.
8.3.4 The type of PPE worn will be based on a risk assessment of the task being carried out, the hazards and the risks associated with the task.

8.3.5 Where PPE is required for undertaking clinical tasks, the type of PPE worn is based upon the assessed risk of clinical intervention to be undertaken. See Infection Control Standard Policy for Standard Precautions for further detail.
Implementation
8.4.1 Managers will in consultation with employees ensure the PPE is used as a last resort (except in certain clinical circumstances).

8.4.2 Managers will ensure appropriate PPE is identified through the risk assessment process and a sufficient stock of PPE is maintained at all times for all the circumstances to ensure the protection of staff and others.
8.4.3 Managers must ensure staff receive the appropriate training, information and instructions in the safe use of all types of PPE before use.

8.4.4 The implementation of this Policy requires the co-operation of all staff. Therefore full consultation with employee representatives through existing channels of communication will be undertaken.
Training
To ensure all wearers know how to use an item of PPE correctly, information, instruction and training must be provided to all those required to wear a particular piece of equipment.

Training should cover theoretical aspects such as the nature of the hazard and how the PPE will protect against it (purpose and manner of use including any limitations of the item in question) and practical considerations including correct fitting of the PPE and any basic items of maintenance or visual inspection that wearers will be expected to undertake prior to use.

The precise content of any training provided will depend on the complexity and required level of performance of the equipment. The frequency of training, including update training, will depend upon similar criteria however manufacturer's guidelines should be used where applicable.

Managers will identify and provide sufficient information, instruction, training, refresher training and where necessary demonstrations in the wearing of PPE to ensure the health and safety of all staff using PPE.
Managers will retain up to date training records.

Managers will ensure The Health and Social Care Act 2012 (Department of Health 2015) principles and practice of prevention and control of infection is included in the induction training programme for new staff and as part of ongoing education for existing staff. Information on standard infection prevention and control principles relevant to this policy are included in the Trust induction and mandatory training sessions.
The Infection Prevention and Control Team offers additional training which includes information contained in this policy as required.
Procurement of PPE

All PPE is to be sourced only and directly through the Trusts Procurement Team. Under no circumstance is PPE to be purchased independently. The Trust uses one examination type glove and has a few choices available for domestic and surgical gloves. If these are deemed not to be suitable / appropriate for the activity / person then following a suitable risk assessment / Occupational Health advice a different glove maybe sourced by the Procurement Team.
Monitoring and Audit

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and Implementation
Approved by MSE University Hospitals Group Health and safety Committee / Management Groups and ratified via the MSE Document Management Group
References & Associated Documents
This procedure should be read in conjunction with the following documents:
Health and Safety Policy
Infection Control Policy
Policy for the Management and Prevention of Patients and Staff Acquiring a Latex Allergy
Work at Height Policy
Handling of Healthcare Waste Policy & Procedures
Policy for Clinical Staff Uniforms and Non-Clinical Staff Dress Code
Hand Decontamination Policy
Medical Equipment Decontamination Policy
Equality Impact Assessment
Each procedural must go through an Equality Impact Assessment (EIA). Please list here the outcome of the one completed (refer to appendix 11)
APPENDIX 1:
LINE MANAGERS RESPONSIBILITIES

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) includes gloves, respirators, footwear and clothing. PPE should not be relied on exclusively to control risks but may be used in conjunction with other control measures, e.g. fume cupboards, local exhaust ventilation or screens etc.

There are a number of pieces of legislation covering this area including the “Personal Protective Equipment and Work Regulations 1992”, “Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations 2002”, and the “Control of Noise at Work Regulations 1989”.
NB: The law requires that PPE be only to be used as a last resort (see 7.2 / 8.3 of this policy for Infection, Prevention and Control activities)
Provision of means other than PPE to control the risk where reasonably practicable
Ensuring PPE is properly selected, i.e. appropriate to the risk
Ensuring PPE is as comfortable as possible for the wearer and fits properly
Ensuring staff are adequately trained in the use of PPE including when to use, how to clean and maintain, and when to discard
Ensuring adequate storage is available for PPE
Ensuring that replacement PPE is available as required
Ensuring PPE is adequately maintained
Ensuring that records of issue, maintenance and training are kept where appropriate
Ensuring that staff make full and proper use of PPE where provided
Ensuring a register of issue and visual inspection of PPE is maintained and kept where appropriate
All PPE must comply with the appropriate British or European Standard (CE marked in accordance with the Personal Protective Equipment Regulations 2002).
Appendix 2:
CHECKLIST FOR CONSIDERING THE APPROPRIATENESS AND SUITABLITY OF PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT (PPE)
PPE will depend on the types of hazards / risks and may require an individual risk assessment to be carried out.
Where in place use the Manufactures Safety Data Sheet to identify the following:
physical / chemical properties
physiological / health effects
occupational exposure limit - if so, are the concentrations in the atmosphere at safe levels?
penetration to the skin falling from a height
electric shock and live working
oven gloves

blood / body fluid spillages - identify if there are any potential risks of exposure to the skin or mucous membranes of blood, body fluids or any other potential source. Blood borne viruses can occur following the splashing of blood on to mucous membranes. Individuals with blood borne diseases cannot be easily identified, therefore, the standard principles required to reduce the transmission of the pathogens should be used in the care of all patients
wound dressings
handling continence products / nappies
handling indwelling urinary catheters/bags / stoma bags
undertaking invasive procedures
caring for patients in isolation facilities
in the event of any risk of coming in to contact with blood or any body fluids
when coming in to contact with a known / suspected infectious patient and / or their immediate environment
when handling all sharps
The User
suitability for the wearer
comfort and fit - consider ergonomic requirements of the user e.g. head / face size and shape and if the user has facial hair
adjustability
health of the user
requirements for communication, visibility and movement
other factors that may prevent safe use of the PPE
Others
contractors
visitors
patients
The Activity
length of time the PPE will need to be worn
the rate of work and physical effort required to do the job
where the work be carried out i.e. indoors / outdoors, on-site / off-site
compatibility with other types of PPE to be worn
Working Environment:
sufficient space for the user to move about safely
working in a confined space
working at height
hindrance of movement for the user
oxygen-deficient atmosphere
extremes of temperature i.e. hot / cold
UV Protection (sun cream of sufficient factor)
adverse weather conditions
Hazards and types of PPE following completion of risk assessment, if higher elements of the controls hierarchy are not fully effective PPE should be considered.
APPENDIX 3
CHECKLIST FOR THE SELECTION OF PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT (PPE) U
PPE must be risk assessed and selected to ensure the required degree of protection for the type of hazard / activity and the associated risks.

Common type of PPE (this list is not exhaustive as other PPE may be required depending on the hazard / activity type for example, where there is risk of injury to the head or health risks to the lungs).
Hands and Arms

Hazards: abrasion, temperature extremes, cuts and punctures, impact, chemicals, electric shock, radiation, vibration, biological agents, vibration and prolonged immersion in water Summary of options: gloves, gauntlets and sleeving that covers part or the entire arm etc.
When considering the type of glove the following must be taken in to account:
Identify the hazard type and risks for example:
Thermal - contact with very hot or cold objects, including sparks or flames when welding or cutting hot metal
Mechanical - the skin can be torn or cut by rough or sharp surfaces
Vibration
Impact
Radiation
Electric shock
Chemical - substances containing strong acids, alkalis, solvents or irritants may cause Dermatitis, ulcers or similar problems.
Exposure to blood, body spillage fluids or any other potential source of infection
Exposure to organic matter and micro organisms

Glove(s) could cause the wearers hands to become contaminated. Should the wearer take the gloves off then put the same gloves back on they could transfer the contaminant to the inner surface of the glove. Gloves must be thoroughly washed before removal to prevent this risk ‘Heavy duty' gloves used for decontaminating equipment must be thoroughly washed before removal to prevent this risk – Note: Gloves used for clinical activities are single use only and must never be re used
Selection

material type – ensure all the physical characteristics and barriers properties are appropriate for the risk. The wrong material type may not afford the correct protection and may also impair sensitivity, finger dexterity and grip strength. Materials must not be able to be penetrated by chemicals (see Health Saftey Executive's ‘Skin at Work' website) size and fit - loose fitting gloves should never be used when using machinery where an entanglement risk exists and if it is too tight a fit it may increase the load on the hand
the task (long gauntlet type gloves or short gloves)

allergies – natural rubber latex remains superior in protecting against blood borne viruses and non-powdered and low protein latex gloves must be worn. Latex gloves which contain power have known risks associated with aerosolisation and increased latex allergies i.e. dermatitis so must not be worn. Nitrile gloves may be considered an alternative to latex. Consider a referral to Occupational Health for staff or patients with allergies / sensitivities to both latex and nitrile gloves
NB Vinyl and polythene gloves must never be used for any aspects of clinical care (RCN 2012)
resistance to the substance type(s) to prevent penetration
disposable single use gloves

sterile gloves – should be used for contact with key parts / sites during Aseptic None Touch Technique (ANTT) (remove surgical as not all ANTT procedures are surgical) procedures and for the preparation of sterile pharmaceutical products
cotton inner gloves – to help prevent skin problems where long periods can make the skin hot and moist
Barrier creams – these are unreliable and are not a substitute for PPE
A selection of suitable gloves will make it easier for users to find a good fit.
A balance may need to be made between comfort, sensitivity of touch, grip and the degree of protection for the job.
Eye / Respiratory / Face Protection Head and neck
Hazards: impact from falling or flying objects, risk of head bumping, hair getting tangled in machinery, chemical drips or splash, climate or temperature.
Suumary of options: a range of Industrial safety helmets and bump caps, hairnets, sun screens
Breathing
Hazards: Oxygen-deficient atmospheres, dusts, gases and vapours etc. Suumary of options: disposable filtering face piece (Dust mask/surgical mask) or respirator, breathing apparatus etc.
Eyes
Hazards: chemical or metal splash, splash or spray of bodily fluid, dust, projectiles, gas and vapour, lasers, radiation etc.
Suumary of options: safety spectacles, over glasses, goggles (including lead goggles), face shields/screens, visors.
N/B. Prescription eyewear does not give sufficient protection. Identify the hazard type and risks for example:
flying chips / particles (from welding equipment, hot cutting metal, against corrosive or irritant chemicals
splashes (from epoxy resins, concrete, blood and body fluid)
dust
chemical
procedures likely to cause splashing of body substances in to the face – surgical, maternal delivery, manual cleaning of instruments, dentistry and podiatry interventions
USelection
comfort and fit
ease of movement
clear visibility
compatibility with other PPE (i.e. spectacles, goggles, visors, respiratory protection equipment (RPE) or hearing protectors)
work environment (note spectacles or visors may steam up in humid or hot conditions)

FFP3 Mask – a disposable particulate filtration, tight facial seal must be worn in the following situations: o when performing procedures that have the potential to generate aerosols on patients known or suspected of having Pandemic Influenza

FFP3 masks must be ‘fit tested' to assess the correct fit around the nose and chin. This must be done either by a suitably qualified / competent person or where staff have received the appropriate training in how to use and adjust fit in accordance with health and safety regulations.
NB: Where a mask becomes contaminated with body fluids it must be changed immediately
Face Fit Testing

The Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations 2002 (as amended) requires respiratory protective equipment (RPE) to be fit tested. In circumstances where RPE is specified the Trust will ensure that an adequate face fit test is carried out in line with the manufacturer's recommendations. This will be arranged via department managers.
Hearing
Hazards: Noise
Suumary of options: Ear plugs or defenders etc.
Identify the hazard type and risks for example:
noise – a combination of sound level and duration of exposure, very high-level sounds re a hazard even with short duration
USelection
ear plugs
ear muffs
semi-inset / canal caps
Choose a protector that will reduce the noise to an acceptable level while allowing for safety and communication.
Foot Protection Feet and legs
Hazards: slips and trips, electrostatic build-up, cuts and punctures, falling objects, heavy loads, chemical splash, vehicles.
Suumary of options: safety boots and shoes, mid-sole wellington boots.
UIdentify the hazard type and risks for example:
crushing
slips
walking onto sharp objects
contact with irritant / corrosive chemicals
falling objects
heavy loads
USelection
strong enough to withstand the stresses placed upon it
protected (steel) toecaps
penetration resistance (a steel mid-sole or similar armoury may be required)
anti-static
electrically conductive
thermally insulating
Protecting the body
Hazards: heat, chemical splash, contaminated dust, impact or penetration, falls from height, entanglement of own clothing, radiation, temperature extremes, adverse weather, vibration
Suumary of options: conventional or disposable overalls or aprons (including lead aprons), boiler suits, hi visibility vests and stab resistant vests, safety harnesses etc.
Plastic Disposable Aprons
UIdentify the hazard type and risks for example:
contamination to the wearer's clothing from the patient
contamination to the wearer from the environment

Aprons must not be re-used or come into contact with more than one patient. Micro- organisms will survive for a sufficient time to allow cross infection to occur if the apron is worn in caring for more than one patient.
The apron must be changed where a patient has two wound dressings or bilateral leg ulcers (Pratt et al 2007)
APPENDIX 4
GUIDANCE FOR DEALING WITH BLOOD / BODY FLUID SPILLAGE U

The guidance in relation to protection against infection with blood borne viruses identifies the risks to staff, particularly the highest risk which is due to inoculation injuries. There is evidence that the transmission of blood borne viruses can occur following the splashing of blood onto mucous membranes. Individuals with blood borne diseases cannot be easily identified therefore, the standard principles required to reduce the transmission of these pathogens should be used in the care of all patients (Health Protection Agency 2005).
Blood or other body fluids spillage may expose staff to blood-borne viruses or other pathogens;
Blood/ Body fluids and spillages include:
handling continence products / nappies
handling catheters / stoma bags
handling sharps (venepuncture)
undertaking invasive procedures
caring for patients in isolated facilities
blood
respiratory and oral secretions
vomit
vaginal secretions
amniotic fluid
faeces
urine
wound dressings / drainage
semen
cerebrospinal fluid
pleural fluid
gastric
aspiration
breast milk
Safety Procedures
All spillages of blood / body fluids must be cleaned up immediately (Refer to ICO08 Blood and Other Body Fluid Spillages Policy).
Minimum Protective Clothing to be worn in all instances
Plastic disposable aprons
Disposable gloves - much be changed between patients and care activities for the same patient and where the gloves have become contaminated
Hands must be decontaminated before applying gloves and again after their removal
Washing gloves or applying Alcohol Hand Rub to gloves is strictly not permitted
Double gloving must not take place for non-surgical procedures or practices. It is only recommended for exposure prone procedures e.g. open surgery and if using cytotoxic preparations (WHO 2009)
eyes and mouth protection - goggles and mask (or full face visor) if splash or spray is likely
Extreme care must be taken to avoid skin, eye and mucous membrane contamination whilst cleaning and disinfection of spillages.
Staff must follow routine infection control standard precautions in all instances when dealing with blood / body fluids and spillages (see Infection, Prevention and Control Policy).
All cuts and lesions must be covered with waterproof dressings when at work.
All exposures to blood / body fluids and spillages must be reported to the Occupational Health Department for advice and the Trusts incident reporting procedures must be followed.
Staff who may be exposed to spillages of blood / body fluids should be vaccinated against hepatitis B virus. Advice should be sought from the Occupational Health Department.
Hand Hygiene
Hand hygiene must always be performed before and after wearing any PPE as this can reduce the risk of transmission of micro-organisms.
Always decontaminate hands after dealing with spillages or contaminated waste (see the Trusts Hand Hygiene Policy and Procedure).

data.text: APPENDIX
REMOVAL AND DISPOSAL OF PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPEMENT (PPE)  U
Removal
PPE must be removed in the order of sequence as per Appendix 5 to minimise the risk of cross/self-contamination.
Gloves, gowns and eye protection should be disposed of as clinical waste when there is a known or suspected infection.
Soiled / used protective clothing and contaminated waste must be disposed of in accordance with the Trusts Management of Waste Policy
Re-usable
Items of protective equipment, such as visors or eye safety goggles should be decontaminated according to manufacturer's instructions.
Disposal

Disposable items in health centres, inpatient and clinic settings should be risk assessed by healthcare professionals in order to ensure that the waste is placed into the appropriate contaminated or household waste streams prior to disposal. (see Trust Waste Management policy)
Disposal of PPE in Patients' Own Homes

Disposal of clinical waste in patient's own homes should be risk assessed on an individual basis with each patient. This should include reviewing the amounts of waste generated including PPE and whether or not the waste is considered infectious.
Hand Hygiene
Always decontaminate hands after removing and disposing of PPE. See The Trusts Hand Hygiene Policy and/or Procedure
APPENDIX 9
MANDATORY SIGNS (Taken from HSE's L64 document)

This assessment relates to: Provision and Safe Use of Personal Protective Equipment Policy / MSEPO-20201

table_items.text: A change in a service to patients
A change to an existing policy
A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?

Review of existing policy in line to elapsed review date. Addition of guidance and practical advice for personal protective equipment. Policy now contains more comprehensive approach as to how regulatory compliance is achieved
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Impart risk based approach arrangements and proactive actions for safe usage of personal protective equipment
Who benefits from this change and how?
All who perform work where they could potentially experience an injury as a result of a perfomaing tasks without personal protection equipment
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No – Personal Protective equipment is issued to individuals ensure safety when performing tasks whereby risk assessment has deemed this necessary.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change? b) If so, with whom?
Yes Trust Health and safety Committee / HR and Occ. Health Colleagues (refer to page 1&2)
